entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 27 at 2:58AM CDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
At 258 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 8 miles southeast of Eglin Air Force Base, or 12 miles northeast of Santa Rosa Beach, moving east at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Eglin Air Force Base, Live Oak, Freeport, Ebro, Hinsons Crossroads, Red Bay, Portland, Rock Hill, Bruce, Red Head, Eucheeanna, Millers Ferry, New Home, and Knox Hill.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 27 at 3:20AM EDT by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
Areas of patchy dense fog will continue to develop across southern Indiana and central Kentucky this morning. Some of the fog will be locally dense, with visibility around a quarter of a mile.
If traveling this morning, be prepared for dense fog to cause a rapid change in visibility. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination. Use low beam headlights in foggy areas.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued June 27 at 12:10AM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Air Quality Health Advisory for Wildfire Smoke.
WHERE...Western Pueblo and eastern Custer Counties. Locations include, but are not limited to Beulah.
WHEN...900 AM Wednesday June 26 to 900 AM Thursday June 27
IMPACTS...The Oak Ridge Fire is burning near the Pueblo/ Custer County line, approximately 3 miles northwest of Beulah. Smoke should begin to dissipate as daytime atmospheric mixing increases. Thunderstorms are possible on Wednesday afternoon, which can produce gusty, erratic winds that could send smoke in any direction. As the wind dies down and smoke settles late Wednesday night into Thursday morning, moderate to heavy smoke is possible in Beulah.
HEALTH INFORMATION...Public Health Recommendations: If smoke is thick or becomes thick in your neighborhood you may want to remain indoors. This is especially true for those with heart disease, respiratory illnesses, the very young, and older adults. Consider limiting outdoor activity when moderate to heavy smoke is present. Consider relocating temporarily if smoke is present indoors and is making you ill. If visibility is less than 5 miles in smoke in your neighborhood, smoke has reached levels that are unhealthy.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 26 at 7:17PM AKDT until June 30 at 7:00PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Warm daytime and overnight temperatures have continued the melting of high elevation snowpack and glacier ice to produce minor flooding along the Chilkat River. Warm temperatures will continue through the week and into the weekend, causing continued daily crests.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by snowmelt continues.
* WHERE...The Chilkat River near areas around Mile Post 14 and 24 of the Haines Highway, near Klukwan and the Chilkat River Bridge.
* WHEN...Until 700 PM AKDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 713 PM AKDT, River gauge reports indicate rises in water levels from snowmelt in areas around mile post 14 and 24 of the Haines Highway, near Klukwan and the Chilkat River Bridge. Minor flooding is ongoing, especially near the Chilkat River.
- Please send reports of impacts and pictures of those impacts with specific location information to the National Weather Service forecast office in Juneau by email (juneau.weather@noaa.gov), or via X, or Facebook.
- For Chilkat River at Klukwan: At 6:00pm the stage was 126.5 feet. Flood Stage is 126.0 feet. Forecast: Crests between 126.0 and 126.8 feet are likely over the next several days. Daily minimums in water levels at the Chilkat River Bridge will occur at around 10pm and daily crests at around 10am are expected.
Impacts: At 126.0 feet: Bankfull stage. Water will begin to flood backyards along the Chilkat River in the village of Klukwan.
At 126.5 feet: Expect flooding of yards and bank erosion near the Jilkaat Kwan Cultural Heritage Center Campus Traditional Knowledge camp in the village of Klukwan. Water will flood lower elevations in backyards along the Chilkat River near Klukwan and start to impact some smokehouse and a river access road. - For the Klehini River: Daily water level peaks at the 26 mile bridge gauge will occur near midnight.
- If you live near or along the Chilkat river, stay alert and be prepared to take action.

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM AKDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 26 at 4:40PM AKDT until June 28 at 12:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Snowmelt is causing additional rises on the Skwentna and Yentna Rivers. Minor flooding is expected through the week.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by snowmelt continues.
* WHERE...Skwentna and Yentna Rivers, and surrounding low-lying areas
* WHEN...Until noon AKDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas, including public boat landings and low-lying airstrips.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - High water, lowland flooding and inundation of low structures will continue in this area. - For Skwentna River at Skwentna: Forecast: Bankfull conditions around 41 feet are expected through the week.

* TIMING...Through early Thursday morning, with waves and surf peaking this afternoon during high tide.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued June 26 at 4:10PM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Air Quality Health Advisory for Wildfire Smoke.
WHERE...Western Pueblo and eastern Custer Counties. Locations include, but are not limited to Beulah.
WHEN...900 AM Wednesday June 26 to 900 AM Thursday June 27
IMPACTS...The Oak Ridge Fire is burning near the Pueblo/ Custer County line, approximately 3 miles northwest of Beulah. Smoke should begin to dissipate as daytime atmospheric mixing increases. Thunderstorms are possible on Wednesday afternoon, which can produce gusty, erratic winds that could send smoke in any direction. As the wind dies down and smoke settles late Wednesday night into Thursday morning, moderate to heavy smoke is possible in Beulah.
HEALTH INFORMATION...Public Health Recommendations: If smoke is thick or becomes thick in your neighborhood you may want to remain indoors. This is especially true for those with heart disease, respiratory illnesses, the very young, and older adults. Consider limiting outdoor activity when moderate to heavy smoke is present. Consider relocating temporarily if smoke is present indoors and is making you ill. If visibility is less than 5 miles in smoke in your neighborhood, smoke has reached levels that are unhealthy.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued June 26 at 1:31PM MDT until June 28 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Portions of Colorado, including the following areas, Animas River Basin, Central Colorado River Basin, Central Gunnison and Uncompahgre River Basin, Central Yampa River Basin, Debeque to Silt Corridor, Elkhead and Park Mountains, Flat Tops, Four Corners/Upper Dolores River, Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys, Grand Valley, Grand and Battlement Mesas, Lower Yampa River Basin, Northwest San Juan Mountains, Paradox Valley/Lower Dolores River, Roan and Tavaputs Plateaus, San Juan River Basin, Southwest San Juan Mountains, Uncompahgre Plateau and Dallas Divide, Upper Gunnison River Valley, Upper Yampa River Basin and West Elk and Sawatch Mountains and Utah, including the following areas, Arches/Grand Flat, Canyonlands/Natural Bridges, La Sal and Abajo Mountains, Southeast Utah and Tavaputs Plateau.
* WHEN...From Thursday afternoon through Thursday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may become flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A strong surge of subtropical moisture combined with a weak upper level disturbance raises the potential for excessive rainfall across the region. Though storms will not be slow moving, training echoes and rainfall rates in excess of 2 inches per hour are possible. Slick rock areas and slot canyons are at greatest risk, but urban flooding is also a concern. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued June 26 at 9:10AM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Air Quality Health Advisory for Wildfire Smoke.
WHERE...Western Pueblo and eastern Custer Counties. Locations include, but are not limited to Beulah.
WHEN...900 AM Wednesday June 26 to 900 AM Thursday June 27
IMPACTS...The Oak Ridge Fire is burning near the Pueblo/ Custer County line, approximately 3 miles northwest of Beulah. Smoke should begin to dissipate as daytime atmospheric mixing increases. Thunderstorms are possible on Wednesday afternoon, which can produce gusty, erratic winds that could send smoke in any direction. As the wind dies down and smoke settles late Wednesday night into Thursday morning, moderate to heavy smoke is possible in Beulah.
HEALTH INFORMATION...Public Health Recommendations: If smoke is thick or becomes thick in your neighborhood you may want to remain indoors. This is especially true for those with heart disease, respiratory illnesses, the very young, and older adults. Consider limiting outdoor activity when moderate to heavy smoke is present. Consider relocating temporarily if smoke is present indoors and is making you ill. If visibility is less than 5 miles in smoke in your neighborhood, smoke has reached levels that are unhealthy.

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY HEALTH ADVISORY FOR WILDFIRE SMOKE FROM 900 AM WEDNESDAY UNTIL 900 AM THURSDAY
